journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Finite-element study of cerebrospinal fluid in mitigating closed head injuries

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Yunhua Luo, Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Manitoba R3T 5V6, Canada. Email: Yunhua.Luo@ad.umanitoba.ca

abstract.p: The mechanism of cerebrospinal fluid in mitigating closed head injuries caused by mild impacts was investigated by finite-element modeling. Three biomechanical models were constructed. In these models, cerebrospinal fluid was considered as a soft solid material, an inviscid fluid without intracranial pressure, and an inviscid fluid with normal intracranial pressure, respectively, while other conditions such as the finite-element mesh, the impact, and the boundary conditions were kept the same. The recently developed nearest nodes finite-element method was adopted to deal with large deformations in brain tissue. Results obtained from the numerical studies showed that cerebrospinal fluid was able to remarkably reduce the maximum peak strains, especially the shear strains induced by impacts and transmitted to the brain. Cerebrospinal fluid with intracranial pressure was able to further buffer relative oscillations between the skull and the brain.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Head injury remains a major cause of mortality in various accidents. Based on a recent survey1 conducted in the United States, each year an estimated 1.7 million people sustain head injuries. Among them, 52,000 die and 275,000 are hospitalized. Therefore, a great research effort has been devoted to studying head injuries, for example, Refs. 2–47, among others. The head is one of the most delicate and the most complicated structures in the world. The brain is the core part that is protected by several layers of tissues. The skull and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are the two major protection layers. Based on the status of the skull, head injuries can be classified into open and closed.2 An open head injury is mainly characterized by fractures in the skull, and a closed head injury (CHI) may occur without any damage to the skull. Open head injuries have been extensively investigated by both experimental and numerical methods, for example, Refs. 2–23. Skull fracture and foreign object penetration into the brain tissue have been identified as the two major mechanical mechanisms in open head injuries. Therefore, open head injuries can be effectively prevented by wearing a protective helmet. Helmetry is especially effective for protecting children from head injuries,24 as the skulls of children have a much lower elastic modulus. The outer hard shell of a helmet is able to prevent a sharp object from penetrating into the skull. However, mechanical mechanisms involved in CHIs are different. In CHIs, although the skull is not broken and the brain tissue is not penetrated by any foreign object, the brain may still be injured. Helmets have been found less effective in preventing CHIs.25–29 CHIs more often occur in daily life accidents and in recreational activities. A CHI can be easily ignored or may not be treated on time, as it does not have any obvious outside sign. Understanding the role of outer tissue layers in protecting the brain is a necessary step for designing more effective helmets to prevent or alleviate CHIs.

CSF is an essential part in the anatomical structure of the head. Its role in protecting the brain from mild impacts has not been fully studied. CSF is a clear liquid that mainly fills in the ventricles, the subarachnoid space, and the spinal channel. For a normal adult, the amount of CSF in the brain is about 135–150 mL.30 Intracranial pressure (ICP) is maintained in CSF, which is normally between 7 and 15 mm of Hg (i.e. between 500 and 2000 Pa)31 for an adult in a supine position. CSF plays several important roles in the human body. Buoyancy from CSF allows the brain to maintain in a float state so that the whole brain is roughly under a uniform pressure. Without CSF, the brain’s own weight would block blood supply and compress neurons in the lower part of the brain. CSF carries sugar and other nutrients that are used by cells in the central nervous system (CNS). It flows throughout the inner ventricular system in the brain and is absorbed back into the bloodstream, rinsing the metabolic waste from the CNS through the blood–brain barrier. Another very important role of CSF is its protection of the brain from various CHIs.

It is very difficult to investigate the protection role played by CSF using cadaver experiments, as in a cadaver, the CSF has either been drained into the spinal channel or it has been solidified. Therefore, a normal ICP cannot be maintained in a cadaver. In vitro models were also developed to investigate the role of CSF in mitigating brain injuries. In Ref. 33, the role of CSF in the cerebral ventricles in relieving strains during head rotation was studied using physical models. Two physical models were tested, one has cerebral ventricles filled with CSF and the other does not. Angular acceleration and deceleration were used as stimuli. However, physical experiment has its limitations for such kinds of studies. For example, in the test, peak strains were observed at a number of prescribed locations, which are usually not the maximum peak strain. The maximum peak strain is a more relevant parameter for studying brain injuries. But it is very difficult to obtain by physical experiment due to the uncertainty of its location. Finite-element modeling has been adopted for the study due to its advantages over physical experimentation. Two dominant categories of finite-element models have been proposed in the literature to represent CSF.8,9,12,15,16,18,20,23,41,48–57 In one category of the models, CSF is modeled as a soft solid material. The constitutive laws adopted for CSF range from elastic with fluid-like properties, to viscoelastic, to nearly incompressible elastic with a low shear modulus and a high bulk modulus. In the other category of models, CSF is considered as a frictional surface between the skull and the brain. The contact conditions on the surface are considered as either tied or sliding. ICP has not been considered in the existing finite-element models. It is noticed that in Ref. 32, a simplified mechanical model is proposed to study the coup–contrecoup phenomenon, a very special CHI44 where contusions may not only occur on the coup site (the impact site) but also on the contrecoup site (opposite to the impact side). In the model, the skull is modeled as a rigid container, the CSF is governed by the incompressible Navier–Stokes equations, and the brain is represented as a rigid solid. Relative motion between the skull and the brain is well modeled. However, strains in the brain tissue, which are important parameters for studying brain injuries, cannot be obtained using this model.

In this research, the mechanism of CSF and ICP in mitigating mild impacts to the head was investigated using finite-element modeling. Three biomechanical models were constructed for the investigation. In the three models, CSF was considered as a soft solid material having a very low elasticity modulus, an inviscid fluid without pressure, and an inviscid fluid with normal ICP, respectively. The other conditions, such as the finite-element mesh, the impact, and the constraint conditions were kept the same.

sec.title: Biomechanical models for studying protection mechanism of CSF
sec.p: The head is complex in both its anatomic structure and its material properties. The anatomic structure of the head consists of many large and small details such as the scalp, skull, dura, pia arachnoid, corpus callosum, ventricles, sulci, cerebral vasculatures, neurons and axons, and so on. Inclusion of all these details in a finite-element model would result in a large number of degrees of freedom and many distorted finite elements in the finite-element model. Finite-element distortion has been recognized as one major issue in finite-element modeling of brain injuries.15,34 Distorted finite elements would produce spurious stress/strain concentrations, which would make finite-element solutions not useful even for qualitative studies. Both the bones and the soft tissues in the head have very complex material properties. They are inhomogeneous, anisotropic, viscoelastic, and loading-rate dependent.35–37,39 Therefore, assumptions and simplifications will be introduced in the following, so that the constructed biomechanical model is adequate for studying the role of CSF, and it requires a reasonable amount of computational time.
The proposed biomechanical model consists of four main parts: the skull, CSF, brain, and facial/neck bones, see Figure 1.

caption.p: Simplified biomechanical model for the head.
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid.

sec.p: The first three parts are essential for the study. The facial/neck bones were included for two reasons. Their mass has considerable effect on the dynamic responses of the whole head, and they are necessary to specify boundary conditions at the neck. CSF in both the ventricles and the subarachnoid space was included in the biomechanical model, although CSF in the subarachnoid space plays a dominant role in providing a cushion to external impacts. The following three models were constructed and used in the investigations.

list-item.p: Model 1 (without CSF): In this model, all the four parts, the skull, brain tissue, CSF, and facial/neck bones, are considered as solid materials with different elasticity moduli. This model is commonly adopted in the literature.
Model 2 (with CSF only): The difference between Model 2 and Model 1 is that in Model 2 CSF is considered as an inviscid fluid and no pressure is applied.
Model 3 (with CSF and ICP): The difference between Model 3 and Model 2 is that a normal constant ICP (1500 Pa)31 is applied to the CSF part.

sec.p: In Models 2 and 3, CSF was considered as an inviscid fluid due to the following consideration: For a closed container (i.e. with no inflow and outflow) completely filled with fluid, interaction between the container wall and the fluid is dominated by pressure; viscous effects induced by deviatoric stresses or fluid friction can be neglected.58 In our study of CHIs, the anatomic structure of the head was considered as a closed container, and the major concern was the stress level in the brain tissues. Compared with stresses produced by pressure wave induced by impact, the stresses transferred from the skull to the brain tissue by CSF due to its friction would be much smaller. For pressure-dominated oscillation and wave propagation, bulk modulus of the brain tissues is required for establishing the governing equations and for calculating wave velocity. The role of CSF in protecting the brain was investigated by comparing the mechanical responses of the three models to the same impact. Maximum peak strains occurring in the brain and collisions between the brain and the skull were used as indicators for potential brain injuries. The objective of the study was to find out how these indicators are affected by the different considerations of CSF and ICP in the three models.

sec.title: Construction of finite-element mesh
sec.p: Three finite-element models were built based on the three biomechanical models. To enhance the bio-fidelity of the finite-element models, finite-element meshes were generated using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans obtained from the Health Science Centre located at Winnipeg, Canada. Official ethics approval was obtained, and personal information of the subject was erased. The MRI scans were processed by Mimics (Materialise, Belgium). The four parts in the biomechanical model (Figure 1) were segmented, and finite-element meshes consisting of tetrahedron elements were generated. One of such finite-element meshes is shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Finite-element mesh.

sec.title: Material properties of head tissues
sec.p: Material properties of head tissues were mainly obtained by experiments of cadavers.35–37 Material properties reported in the literature are quite diverse, due to differences in subject age, gender, experiment conditions, dependence on anatomic site, and so on.2 Although more advanced material models are available for head tissues, the commonly used material models were adopted in this study. In CHIs, the magnitude of the impact is relatively small and no fracture occurs in the skull. Therefore, a linear isotropic elastic material model was adopted for the skull and for the facial/neck bones. A smaller elastic modulus was used for the facial/neck bones to consider the constraint conditions at the neck and allow large displacement and rotation of the head. Based on experimental analysis of CSF conducted by McElhaney et al.59 and reviewed by Goldsmith,2 normal CSF is a colorless and slightly alkaline liquid composed of 99% of water with a specific gravity around 1.040 that contains very few lipids and proteins but no red blood cells. The brain tissues are typical viscoelastic materials.36,39,60 However, considering that the duration of impacts causing head injuries is very short, in several milliseconds,40 relaxation and creep of the material would not take effect in such a short time. The brain tissue can thus be represented by a hyperelastic material model,39 mainly to consider its large deformation during impact. Based on experimental measurements made by Galford and McElhaney,61 the averaged mass density of brain tissues is very close to that of CSF. Therefore, in most finite-element models proposed in the literature, the same mass density is used for the brain and for the CSF, for example, in the finite-element models proposed by Ruan,9,41 Al-Bsharat et al.,62 and Ueno and Melvin.63 The material properties required in the three biomechanical models were retrieved from the literature16,23,36,38,64,65 and listed in Table 1.

caption.p: Biomechanical properties of human head components

sec.p: The Mooney–Rivlin hyperelastic material model64 was adopted for the brain tissue. In the model, the strain energy density is given by

where I1 and I2 are the first and second invariants of the deviatoric components of the left Cauchy–Green deformation tensor, J is the determinant of the deformation gradient, d is the material incompressibility parameter, and c01 and c10 are empirical material constants determined by the experiments39

sec.title: Impact force and constraint conditions
sec.p: The cadaver experiment conducted by Nahum et al.40 was widely used by researchers to validate their finite-element models.2,41–43 For this reason, the impact force described in Ref. 40 (Experiment No. 37) was also considered in this study. The impact force from the rigid mass was converted into a pressure pulse in a semisinusoidal form. The resulting pressure pulse has a peak value of 0.79 kN/cm2 and a duration of 7 ms. The pulse pressure was uniformly applied over an area of 10 cm2 at the application location indicated in Figure 1. The actual constraint conditions during a head impact are complicated due to the complexity in the anatomic structure of the neck. In this study, the bottom surface of the neck (Figure 1) was completely fixed.

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p: Based on the abovementioned assumptions, governing equations were established. In the absence of body force, wave propagation in a solid medium is governed by66

where σ is the stress tensor; ∇ is the differential operator; μ is a set of parameters describing the material damping property, which are taken as zeros for the skull; ρ is the mass density of solid material; u is the displacement vector; and the superposed dots denote the material time derivatives of the variable.
Wave propagation in a fluid is governed by66
where c=k/ρ0 is the sound speed in a fluid medium, k is the bulk modulus of the fluid, ρ0 is the fluid density, p is the acoustic pressure, and t is the time variable.
Interaction between a fluid and a solid part is introduced by58
where n is the normal of the solid–fluid interface pointing to the fluid region.

sec.title: Finite-element equations
sec.p: Finite-element equations were established by following the procedure in the nearest-nodes finite-element method (NN-FEM).67,68 The NN-FEM is different from the conventional finite-element method by its way of constructing shape functions. In the NN-FEM, nodes from the neighbor elements are available for constructing shape functions in an element. By adopting this strategy, the NN-FEM is able to deal with very large material deformations,69 and it is much less sensitive to element distortion.70 In Model 1, all parts in the biomechanical model (Figure 1) are considered as solid materials. Therefore, only the governing equation (3) is involved. The finite-element equation is obtained as

where u~ is a vector containing element nodal displacements; u~· and u~·· are velocities and accelerations at element nodes, respectively; f(t) is the force vector resulting from the impulse pressure; and Ms, Cs, and Ks are the mass matrix, damping matrix, and tangent stiffness matrix, respectively. Their expressions are given in the following
In Models 2 and 3, CSF was considered as an inviscid fluid, and all the governing equations from (3) to (5) are involved. The obtained finite-element equation is

In equation (8), p~, p~·, and p~·· are the discrete pressures and their first- and second-time derivatives at element nodes in the CSF domain. The matrices, Mf, Cf, Kf, Mfs, and Ksf, appearing in equation (8), are defined as

In equations (7) and (9), Nu and Np are the element shape functions for the displacements and for the pressure field, respectively. In the NN-FEM, higher order shape functions can be constructed for a finite-element mesh consisting of only four-node tetrahedron elements. Bu and Bp are the B matrices obtained by operating the shape functions, Nu and Np, with the corresponding differential operators. D is the material property matrix for the solid components. Ωs and Ωf are the subdomains occupied by the solid and the fluid, respectively. S is the interface surface between solid parts and the CSF.

sec.title: Model stiffness with ICP
sec.p: In Model 3, a normal ICP of 1500 Pa was applied on the CSF part. The pressure would introduce initial stress fields in the skull and in the brain before the model is subjected to an impact. The initial stresses were obtained by a static analysis. The initial stress fields were considered in the contribution to the model stiffness. Therefore, in the dynamic analysis, the model stiffness included two parts: one is the ordinary structural stiffness and the other is contributed by the initial stress field.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p: A time-domain convergence study was first conducted to determine a proper time-step length. The obtained convergence curve, expressed by the variation of the maximum peak effective strain over the whole brain versus time-step length, is shown in Figure 3. A time-step length of 0.01 ms was found adequate for all the three models and was used in obtaining the following finite-element results.

caption.p: Variation of maximum peak effective strain versus length of time step.
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid; ICP: intracranial pressure.

sec.p: A mesh convergence study was then conducted. The variation of the maximum peak effective strain over the whole brain versus the number of elements is displayed in Figure 4. It was found from the study that a finite-element mesh consisting of 169,026 elements was adequate for all the three models to produce converged finite-element solutions. Elements in the mesh are grouped by the parts they belong to and are listed in Table 2.

caption.p: Variation of maximum peak effective strain versus number of elements.
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid; ICP: intracranial pressure.
Statistics of the finite-element mesh

sec.p: The same finite-element mesh was used for the three models to eliminate the effect of the finite-element mesh on the results. The only intended difference in the three models was how the CSF is represented, that is, by solid or fluid and the corresponding material properties assigned to the CSF part.

The mechanism of CSF and ICP in mitigating CHIs was investigated by studying the differences in the mechanical responses predicted by the three models. It has been found in previous studies2,34,40,44 that large ICP and excessive collisions between the brain and the skull are responsible for coup–contrecoup brain injuries. The maximum peak effective strain is directly related to various brain injuries.45,46 Difference in strains at a fixed location provides a direct comparison for the three models. Based on the above considerations, the following four groups of mechanical responses were obtained. The locations where the mechanical responses were obtained are indicated in Figure 5.

caption.p: A transverse plane sliced from the impact location (‘A’ is a point located at the edge of the brain. ‘B’ is a point adjacent to ‘A’ but located on the inner edge of the skull).
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid.

list-item.p: ICP at the coup site (the frontal lobe) and the contrecoup site (the occipital lobe);
Relative motions between the skull (‘B’ in Figure 5) and the brain (‘A’) at the coup site;
Strains at a fixed location (‘A’) in the brain tissue at the coup site; and
The maximum peak effective strain occurring in the whole brain.

sec.p: It should be pointed out that from the point of view of mechanics, a normal ICP in Model 3 has already introduced initial strains in the head tissues. However, these strains have become a part of the physiological status of the human body via the so-called homeostatic adaptation process. Therefore, for the results reported in the following, only the ICP, displacements, and strains induced by the impact were considered for Model 3.

For Model 1, as all the parts were represented as solid materials, ICP was therefore not available in this model. ICPs obtained by Models 2 and 3 are shown in Figure 6. Experiment results obtained by Nahum et al.40 were also plotted for comparison. From Figure 6, it can be observed that the predicted ICPs are in good agreement with the experimental data. It can also be noticed that the ICP predicted by Model 3 has a higher variation frequency, possibly due to the initial ICP and the interaction between the CSF and the solid tissues.

caption.p: ICP induced by the impact: (a) coup site pressure and (b) contrecoup site pressure.
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid; ICP: intracranial pressure.

sec.p: The relative displacements, relative velocities, and relative accelerations between ‘A’ and ‘B’ are shown in Figure 7. From Figure 7, it can be seen that the peak relative velocity and the peak relative acceleration predicted by Model 2 are much larger than those predicted by the other two models. It suggests that if there is no pressure in CSF, collisions between the brain and the skull induced by an impact would be more intensive. Therefore, ICP has the effect of prestressing and increasing the stiffness of the model.

caption.p: Relative motions between the brain (‘A’) and the skull (‘B’): (a) relative displacement, (b) relative velocity, and (c) relative acceleration.
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid; ICP: intracranial pressure.

sec.p: The strains in the brain tissue at the coup site (‘A’ in Figure 5) are plotted in Figure 8. The maximum peak principal strains and the maximum peak effective strain occurring in the whole brain are listed in Table 3. It should be noted that the locations where the maximum peak principal strains as well as the maximum peak effective strain occurred in the three models are different.

caption.p: Strains in the brain tissue at location ‘A’ induced by the impact: (a) εx, (b) εy, (c) shear strain γxy, and (d) effective strain εeff.
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid; ICP: intracranial pressure.
Maximum peak principal strains (ε1max, ε2max, and ε3max) and the effective strain (εeffmax) in the brain (with reduction percentage compared with Model 1)

fn.p: CSF: cerebrospinal fluid; ICP: intracranial pressure.

sec.p: From the strains shown in Figure 8, the maximum peak principal strains and the maximum peak effective strains listed in Table 3, it can be seen that CSF has a remarkable effect in mitigating strains induced by impact. The most significant reductions that can be observed from Figure 8 are in shear strains. Compared with a solid material, a fluid has a very lower tensile and shear modulus, and therefore, it has no ability to withstand tensile and shear strains. By comparing Models 1 and 2, the reductions in the maximum peak principal strains and in the maximum peak effective strain are approximately 40%, which is consistent with the experiment results reported in Ref. 33. The reductions are much more significant in Model 3 where a normal ICP was applied to the CSF. As the maximum peak principal strains and the maximum peak effective strain are more directly related to focal brain injuries, the obtained results suggest that CSF with a normal ICP provides the maximum protection for the brain against mild impacts.

Wave propagation at a number of time instants over the transverse plane where the impact was applied is shown in Figure 9. It was found that the maximum peak effective strain occurred in the frontal lobe at about 4 ms after the impact. The location of the maximum effective strain is consistent with the clinical observations reported in Ref. 71, that is, frontal impacts always result in frontal lobe injuries.

caption.p: Effective strains in the brain (Model 3) at different time instants after impact.

sec.p: Distribution of ICP along the anteroposterior cord starting from the impact location at two time instants is plotted in Figure 10.

caption.p: Distributions of intracranial pressure (Model 3) along the anteroposterior cord at two time instants: (a) t = 2 ms and (b) t = 6 ms.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A general observation that can be made from the obtained results is that there are big differences among the three models, especially between the models with and without CSF. This observation suggests that in a biomechanical model used for studying brain injuries, CSF should not be considered as a solid material and ICP should be considered. The results show that CSF does provide a natural protection for the brain against mild impacts. It is able to considerably reduce the maximum peak principal strains, the maximum peak effective strain, and especially the maximum peak shear strains induced by an impact. These strains have been found to be directly related to various focal brain injuries. A normal ICP is able to further increase the cushion of CSF and thus alleviates collisions between the skull and the brain. CSF with a normal ICP, therefore, plays an optimal role in mitigating coup–contrecoup brain injuries. The above conclusions may provide a clue for designing more effective helmets. If a layer of pressurized fluid or air is added to the conventional helmets between the helmet shell and the padding layer, the helmets may be more effective in preventing CHIs.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The reported research has been supported by an Establishment Grant awarded to the first author by the Manitoba Health Research Council (MHRC), which is gratefully acknowledged.
